Award.AwardTitle: CBMS National Forum on Content-Based Professional Development for Teachers of Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Conference Board for the Mathematical Sciences (CBMS) is organizing and hosting a National Forum on Content-Based Professional Development for Teachers of Mathematics. The conference continues and expands in a new direction work begun at two previous CBMS Forums. The current forum focuses on content-based professional development that is related to the Common Core State Standards for school mathematics recently released by the National Governors Association (NGA) and the Council of Chief State School Officers (CCSSO). The purpose of this third forum is to provide the participants with a better understanding of the features of high quality content-based professional development for teachers of mathematics and to increase the number of college and university mathematics departments who partner with state departments and local school districts to provide such professional development to working teachers.

The forum features speakers and participants involved in the development of the Common Core State Standards, mathematicians, mathematics education professionals with expertise in teacher professional development, and state and school district personnel.

The conference report will be disseminated widely and the discussions at the forum will provide a critical foundation for the revision of the 2001 CBMS report The Mathematical Education of Teachers (MET). The revised MET will be disseminated broadly through the CBMS participating professional organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Approximately 175 participants attended this third CBMS national forum held on October 10-12, 2010.  The participant group included represenatives from 15 of the 17 CBMS member societies, from 26 other non-profit organizations, and from over 40 different colleges and universities, 25 state and local school systems, and 10 publishers and other commercial entities. The Forum focused on ways the mathematical sciences community could work toward a major scaling up of  of mathematics learning opportunities for classroom teachers of mathematics. The widespread adoption of the Common Core State Standards has created a great need for such content-based professional development. The long term goal is not only to scale up professional development opportunities for mathematics teachers, but also to get these opportunities into our systems so they are a part of the on-going responsibilities of departments and other organizations and thus can be factored into the planning of school districts.  The forum featured both presentations and working sessions.  Written versions of the speakers' presentations are posted on the CBMS website at www.cbmsweb.org. The breakout working sessions were designed to engage the participants in working toward the goal of increasing the number of college and university mathematics departments who partner with state departments and local school districts to provide such professional development to working teachers.   The recommendations that emerged from these working sessions were compiled into a white paper 'Common Standards and the Mathematical Education of Teachers' which is posted on the CBMS website at www.cbmsweb.org/Forum3/CBMS_Forum_White_Paper.pdf.   But more important than this set of specific recommendations was the infomation exchange among the participants and the deepening commitment of these community leaders to improve and expand the opportunities for  the continuing mathematical education of teachers of mathematics.
